snippet: New research suggests that trees in at least some parts of the world are having to pull less water out of the ground to achieve a given amount of growth.
abstract: Research paper published in journal Nature suggests that trees in at least some parts of the world are having to pull less water out of the ground to achieve a given amount of growth; some scientists believe this may be direct response to rising level of carbon dioxide in the air from human emissions, though that has not yet been proved; findings complicate picture of how global warming impacts forests.
lead_paragraph: New research suggests that trees in at least some parts of the world are having to pull less water out of the ground to achieve a given amount of growth.

headline.main: Some Trees Use Less Water Amid Rising Carbon Dioxide, Paper Says
headline.print_headline: Some Trees Use Less Water Amid Rising Carbon Dioxide, Paper Says
